elements.content: A luminescent triarylboron ligand functionalized with three carboxylic groups has been synthesized and fully characterized. Its use in boron-containing metal–organic frameworks (B-MOFs) has been demonstrated by the synthesis and isolation of a ZnIIB-MOF compound (B-MOF-1). The crystals of B-MOF-1 belong to the cubic space group F432 with 8-fold interpenetrated networks and ∼21% void space. B-MOF-1 exhibits blue fluorescence and is capable of modest gas sorption of N2, argon, and CO2.
elements.clean_text: A luminescent triarylboron ligand functionalized with three carboxylic groups has been synthesized and fully characterized. Its use in boron-containing metal-organic frameworks (B-MOFs) has been demonstrated by the synthesis and isolation of a ZnIIB-MOF compound (B-MOF-1). The crystals of B-MOF-1 belong to the cubic space group F432 with 8-fold interpenetrated networks and ~21% void space. B-MOF-1 exhibits blue fluorescence and is capable of modest gas sorption of N2, argon, and CO2.

elements.content:
A tricarboxylic-functionalized triarylboron ligand has been synthesized and used to self-assemble the first luminescent boron-containing zinc carboxylate metal−organic framework.

Carboxylate-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are among the most extensively investigated and most robust MOF systems. Recent research of MOFs has focused on the development of functional substrates that are capable of gas storage, light harvesting, catalysis, proton conduction, chemical sensing, or drug delivery. Examples of luminescent MOF systems are especially interesting because they may be used as highly effective sensory systems, where the origin of emission can be from either the backbone ligands, the metal centers (e.g., many lanthanide-based MOFs), or the luminescent guest molecules. With the aim of developing potential solid-state sensing systems for gas molecules, we recently initiated the investigation of triarylboron-containing MOFs. This study is motivated by the fact that Lewis acidic triarylboryl groups are usually luminescent and capable of binding to and sensing small guest molecules such as fluoride and cyanide. Thus, the incorporation of triaryboryl units into MOFs can provide new functionality and capability to the MOF architecture.
elements.clean_text:
A tricarboxylic-functionalized triarylboron ligand has been synthesized and used to self-assemble the first luminescent boron-containing zinc carboxylate metal-organic framework.

Carboxylate-based metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are among the most extensively investigated and most robust MOF systems. Recent research of MOFs has focused on the development of functional substrates that are capable of gas storage, light harvesting, catalysis, proton conduction, chemical sensing, or drug delivery. Examples of luminescent MOF systems are especially interesting because they may be used as highly effective sensory systems, where the origin of emission can be from either the backbone ligands, the metal centers (e.g., many lanthanide-based MOFs), or the luminescent guest molecules. With the aim of developing potential solid-state sensing systems for gas molecules, we recently initiated the investigation of triarylboron-containing MOFs. This study is motivated by the fact that Lewis acidic triarylboryl groups are usually luminescent and capable of binding to and sensing small guest molecules such as fluoride and cyanide. Thus, the incorporation of triaryboryl units into MOFs can provide new functionality and capability to the MOF architecture.

elements.content: We have shown recently that the introduction of a carboxylate group to a triarylboron molecule can lead to facile syntheses of discrete triarylboron-containing bimetallic compounds such as copper(II) carboxylate paddlewheel complexes and lanthanide compounds. We now report the extension of this system into three dimensions as the first example of a luminescent zinc(II) carboxylate metal–organoboron framework (B-MOF). The porosity and luminescent response of the new B-MOF toward gas uptake have been examined. The only previously reported examples of B-MOFs are based on a neutral linker tris(4-pyridyl)durylborane and were not evaluated for gas-uptake capacities.
elements.clean_text: We have shown recently that the introduction of a carboxylate group to a triarylboron molecule can lead to facile syntheses of discrete triarylboron-containing bimetallic compounds such as copper(II) carboxylate paddlewheel complexes and lanthanide compounds. We now report the extension of this system into three dimensions as the first example of a luminescent zinc(II) carboxylate metal-organoboron framework (B-MOF). The porosity and luminescent response of the new B-MOF toward gas uptake have been examined. The only previously reported examples of B-MOFs are based on a neutral linker tris(4-pyridyl)durylborane and were not evaluated for gas-uptake capacities.

elements.content: Ligand 1, a C 3-symmetric star-shaped molecule, was synthesized (Scheme ) by Suzuki coupling of tris(4-bromoduryl)borane (2) with excess boronic acid (3), yielding the triester (82% yield), followed by saponification with LiOH (89% yield). Free ligand 1 exhibits purple-blue fluorescence at 397 nm (λex = 330 nm, THF, 298 K, Φ = 0.03), which is comparable to the monotopic carboxylate ligand that we previously reported. Crystals of 1 obtained from a toluene and methanol solution belong to the monoclinic space group P21/c. In the crystal lattice, molecules of 1 form an extended, interweaved 2D hydrogen-bonded network via the three carboxylic groups, as shown in Figure . Toluene solvent molecules are found within and between the 2D networks of 1 (see the , SI).
elements.clean_text: Ligand 1, a C 3-symmetric star-shaped molecule, was synthesized (Scheme ) by Suzuki coupling of tris(4-bromoduryl)borane (2) with excess boronic acid (3), yielding the triester (82% yield), followed by saponification with LiOH (89% yield). Free ligand 1 exhibits purple-blue fluorescence at 397 nm (λex = 330 nm, THF, 298 K, Φ = 0.03), which is comparable to the monotopic carboxylate ligand that we previously reported. Crystals of 1 obtained from a toluene and methanol solution belong to the monoclinic space group P21/c. In the crystal lattice, molecules of 1 form an extended, interweaved 2D hydrogen-bonded network via the three carboxylic groups, as shown in Figure . Toluene solvent molecules are found within and between the 2D networks of 1 (see the , SI).

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthetic Procedures of L-1 and B-MOF-1

elements.content: Crystal structure of ligand 1 (H atoms removed for clarity): (a) illustration of the hydrogen-bonded network and the locations of toluene molecules (pink, boron; gray, carbon; red, oxygen); (b) space-filling diagram showing the interweaving hydrogen-bonded network.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of ligand 1 (H atoms removed for clarity): (a) illustration of the hydrogen-bonded network and the locations of toluene molecules (pink, boron; gray, carbon; red, oxygen); (b) space-filling diagram showing the interweaving hydrogen-bonded network.

elements.content: The ability of ligand 1 to form B-MOFs is demonstrated by the successful synthesis of B-MOF-1 via solvothermal conditions by reacting ligand 1 and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 95 °C for 3 days in a sealed tube. Single crystals of B-MOF-1, which nucleated on the side of the reaction vessel during the course of the reaction, were isolated in 62% yield. The crystalline solid exhibits blue emission characteristic of the triarylboryl moiety at 402 nm (λex = 330 nm, 298 K, Φ = 0.29; see Figures S5 and S6 in the ). Elemental analysis indicated that B-MOF-1 has the composition of Zn1.5[L-1 3–](H2O)3[(NH2Me2)NO3](DMF)0.5, while X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis confirmed that the B-MOF-1 framework has the composition of Zn1.5[L-1 3–](H2O).
elements.clean_text: The ability of ligand 1 to form B-MOFs is demonstrated by the successful synthesis of B-MOF-1 via solvothermal conditions by reacting ligand 1 and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 95 °C for 3 days in a sealed tube. Single crystals of B-MOF-1, which nucleated on the side of the reaction vessel during the course of the reaction, were isolated in 62% yield. The crystalline solid exhibits blue emission characteristic of the triarylboryl moiety at 402 nm (λex = 330 nm, 298 K, Φ = 0.29; see Figures S5 and S6 in the ). Elemental analysis indicated that B-MOF-1 has the composition of Zn1.5[L-1 3-](H2O)3[(NH2Me2)NO3](DMF)0.5, while X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis confirmed that the B-MOF-1 framework has the composition of Zn1.5[L-1 3-](H2O).

elements.content: The crystal data of B-MOF-1 were collected several times. The quality of the XRD data of B-MOF-1 is consistently poor because of the crystals’ small dimensions and the difficulty in locating/modeling guest/salt molecules inside the lattice. Nonetheless, we were able to establish the key features of the framework (Figures and ). B-MOF-1 belongs to the chiral cubic space group F432. There are two distinct environments for the ZnII ions: dinuclear paddlewheel sites with tetrahedral geometry and mononuclear chelate sites with distorted octahedral geometry (Figure a). The ZnII ions are disordered over these sites, with a total occupancy factor of ∼80% and ∼20% for the tetrahedral and octahedral sites, respectively (see the ). On the tetrahedral sites, the ZnII ions are bound by four O atoms (three from the three bridging carboxylates and one from H2O). On the octahedral sites, the ZnII ions are chelated by three carboxylates. Both B and Zn atoms occupy the C 3 sites. The ZnII ions and the trigonally arranged ligand 1 each serve as a triangular linker, forming a large chiral cage (Figure b) involving seven ZnII units and seven boron units, which are further extended into a 3D 8-fold interpenetrated network via the same linkers (see Figure and the ). Compared to the crystals of ligand 1 that collapse rapidly upon removal from solution, the crystals of B-MOF-1 are highly robust and do not show any apparent change after being subjected to high vacuum, supporting the high stability of the B-MOF framework.
elements.clean_text: The crystal data of B-MOF-1 were collected several times. The quality of the XRD data of B-MOF-1 is consistently poor because of the crystals' small dimensions and the difficulty in locating/modeling guest/salt molecules inside the lattice. Nonetheless, we were able to establish the key features of the framework (Figures  and ). B-MOF-1 belongs to the chiral cubic space group F432. There are two distinct environments for the ZnII ions: dinuclear paddlewheel sites with tetrahedral geometry and mononuclear chelate sites with distorted octahedral geometry (Figure a). The ZnII ions are disordered over these sites, with a total occupancy factor of ~80% and ~20% for the tetrahedral and octahedral sites, respectively (see the ). On the tetrahedral sites, the ZnII ions are bound by four O atoms (three from the three bridging carboxylates and one from H2O). On the octahedral sites, the ZnII ions are chelated by three carboxylates. Both B and Zn atoms occupy the C 3 sites. The ZnII ions and the trigonally arranged ligand 1 each serve as a triangular linker, forming a large chiral cage (Figure b) involving seven ZnII units and seven boron units, which are further extended into a 3D 8-fold interpenetrated network via the same linkers (see Figure  and the ). Compared to the crystals of ligand 1 that collapse rapidly upon removal from solution, the crystals of B-MOF-1 are highly robust and do not show any apparent change after being subjected to high vacuum, supporting the high stability of the B-MOF framework.

elements.content: (a) Diagram showing the environment around the ZnII ions and the disordered ZnII sites (H atoms are omitted for clarity). (b) Diagram showing the single cage and connectivity in B-MOF-1. The central ZnII ions (Zn3A and Zn3B) occupying the chelate sites and the aryl groups around the B atom are omitted (pink, boron; gray, carbon; red, oxygen; turquoise, zinc).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Diagram showing the environment around the ZnII ions and the disordered ZnII sites (H atoms are omitted for clarity). (b) Diagram showing the single cage and connectivity in B-MOF-1. The central ZnII ions (Zn3A and Zn3B) occupying the chelate sites and the aryl groups around the B atom are omitted (pink, boron; gray, carbon; red, oxygen; turquoise, zinc).

elements.content: Despite the high degree of interpenetration, the crystals of B-MOF-1 possess modest porosity as revealed by X-ray data (21% of void space; pore volume of 0.18 cm3 g–1 calculated from the crystal density 1.175 g cm–3 accounting for Zn1.5[L-1 –3](H2O)[(NH2Me2)NO3]. As shown in Figure , three different spherical void spaces of approximately 1.4, 0.7, and 0.2 nm in diameter are present in the crystal lattice. The porosity was further probed via gas physisorption analyses using both N2 and argon as the probe gases. The argon adsorption–desorption isotherms of B-MOF-1 are shown in Figure a as linear and semilogarithmic-scale plots. For comparison, the corresponding N2 adsorption data are presented in Figure S10 in the . In both cases, the isotherms are characteristic of a microporous material, with a type I isotherm, typical for most MOF materials. The physicochemical parameters derived from the inert gas adsorption analysis are compiled in Table S2 in the . The argon Brunauer–Emmett–Teller specific surface area and pore volume obtained for B-MOF-1 are 368 m2 g–1 and 0.19 cm3 g–1, respectively (ca. 406 m2 g–1 and 0.21 cm3 g–1 from the N2 sorption analysis), in good agreement with data from XRD analysis. Advanced pore-size analysis was performed by applying modern nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) method on the argon data assuming a cylindrical pore model for zeolitic/oxidic pores (see the ). The theoretical NLDFT isotherm fits the experimental data very well (see Figure S11 in the ). The data indicate that B-MOF-1 consists of mainly micropores of diameters approximately 1.2 nm and less.

As shown in Figure , three different spherical void spaces of approximately 1.4, 0.7, and 0.2 nm in diameter are present in the crystal lattice. The porosity was further probed via gas physisorption analyses using both N2 and argon as the probe gases. The argon adsorption-desorption isotherms of B-MOF-1 are shown in Figure a as linear and semilogarithmic-scale plots. For comparison, the corresponding N2 adsorption data are presented in Figure S10 in the . In both cases, the isotherms are characteristic of a microporous material, with a type I isotherm, typical for most MOF materials. The physicochemical parameters derived from the inert gas adsorption analysis are compiled in Table S2 in the . The argon Brunauer-Emmett-Teller specific surface area and pore volume obtained for B-MOF-1 are 368 m2 g-1 and 0.19 cm3 g-1, respectively (ca. 406 m2 g-1 and 0.21 cm3 g-1 from the N2 sorption analysis), in good agreement with data from XRD analysis. Advanced pore-size analysis was performed by applying modern nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) method on the argon data assuming a cylindrical pore model for zeolitic/oxidic pores (see the ). The theoretical NLDFT isotherm fits the experimental data very well (see Figure S11 in the ). The data indicate that B-MOF-1 consists of mainly micropores of diameters approximately 1.2 nm and less.

elements.content: 3D structure of B-MOF-1 showing the porous spaces by yellow spheres (pink, boron; gray, carbon; red, oxygen; turquoise polyhedra, zinc).
elements.clean_text: 3  3D structure of B-MOF-1 showing the porous spaces by yellow spheres (pink, boron; gray, carbon; red, oxygen; turquoise polyhedra, zinc).

elements.content: Adsorption–desorption isotherms of B-MOF-1 with Ar at 87 K. Inset: isotherms plotted in a semilogarithmic scale.
elements.clean_text: 4  Adsorption-desorption isotherms of B-MOF-1 with Ar at 87 K. Inset: isotherms plotted in a semilogarithmic scale.

elements.content: Both Ar and N2 isotherms show an adsorption–desorption hysteresis over a wide pressure range, with loops that never close; i.e., low pressure adsorption hysteresis is observed as well. The cause of this phenomenon is not understood yet, and further investigation is required to properly characterize this effect. B-MOF-1 has also been found to adsorb CO2 gas (see the ).
elements.clean_text: Both Ar and N2 isotherms show an adsorption-desorption hysteresis over a wide pressure range, with loops that never close; i.e., low pressure adsorption hysteresis is observed as well. The cause of this phenomenon is not understood yet, and further investigation is required to properly characterize this effect. B-MOF-1 has also been found to adsorb CO2 gas (see the ).

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized the first triarylboron-functionalized carboxylate MOF. Its structure exhibits an 8-fold interpenetrated network, leaving only small pores capable of modest gas uptake. Current efforts are focused on the synthesis of noninterpenetrated B-MOFs to create larger pore volumes and thus enhancement of the gas-uptake capacity.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully synthesized the first triarylboron-functionalized carboxylate MOF. Its structure exhibits an 8-fold interpenetrated network, leaving only small pores capable of modest gas uptake. Current efforts are focused on the synthesis of noninterpenetrated B-MOFs to create larger pore volumes and thus enhancement of the gas-uptake capacity.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic data in CIF format, experimental data, syntheses, powder XRD pattern, photophysical properties, physisorption analysis, and X-ray crystal structure data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: X-ray crystallographic data in CIF format, experimental data, syntheses, powder XRD pattern, photophysical properties, physisorption analysis, and X-ray crystal structure data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
A luminescent triarylboron ligand functionalized with three carboxylic groups has been synthesized and fully characterized. Its use in boron-containing metal–organic frameworks (B-MOFs) has been demonstrated by the synthesis and isolation of a ZnIIB-MOF compound (B-MOF-1). The crystals of B-MOF-1 belong to the cubic space group F432 with 8-fold interpenetrated networks and ∼21% void space. B-MOF-1 exhibits blue fluorescence and is capable of modest gas sorption of N2, argon, and CO2.

Ligand 1, a C 3-symmetric star-shaped molecule, was synthesized (Scheme ) by Suzuki coupling of tris(4-bromoduryl)borane (2) with excess boronic acid (3), yielding the triester (82% yield), followed by saponification with LiOH (89% yield). Free ligand 1 exhibits purple-blue fluorescence at 397 nm (λex = 330 nm, THF, 298 K, Φ = 0.03), which is comparable to the monotopic carboxylate ligand that we previously reported. Crystals of 1 obtained from a toluene and methanol solution belong to the monoclinic space group P21/c. In the crystal lattice, molecules of 1 form an extended, interweaved 2D hydrogen-bonded network via the three carboxylic groups, as shown in Figure . Toluene solvent molecules are found within and between the 2D networks of 1 (see the , SI).

Despite the high degree of interpenetration, the crystals of B-MOF-1 possess modest porosity as revealed by X-ray data (21% of void space; pore volume of 0.18 cm3 g–1 calculated from the crystal density 1.175 g cm–3 accounting for Zn1.5[L-1 –3](H2O)[(NH2Me2)NO3]. As shown in Figure , three different spherical void spaces of approximately 1.4, 0.7, and 0.2 nm in diameter are present in the crystal lattice. The porosity was further probed via gas physisorption analyses using both N2 and argon as the probe gases. The argon adsorption–desorption isotherms of B-MOF-1 are shown in Figure a as linear and semilogarithmic-scale plots. For comparison, the corresponding N2 adsorption data are presented in Figure S10 in the . In both cases, the isotherms are characteristic of a microporous material, with a type I isotherm, typical for most MOF materials. The physicochemical parameters derived from the inert gas adsorption analysis are compiled in Table S2 in the . The argon Brunauer–Emmett–Teller specific surface area and pore volume obtained for B-MOF-1 are 368 m2 g–1 and 0.19 cm3 g–1, respectively (ca. 406 m2 g–1 and 0.21 cm3 g–1 from the N2 sorption analysis), in good agreement with data from XRD analysis. Advanced pore-size analysis was performed by applying modern nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) method on the argon data assuming a cylindrical pore model for zeolitic/oxidic pores (see the ). The theoretical NLDFT isotherm fits the experimental data very well (see Figure S11 in the ). The data indicate that B-MOF-1 consists of mainly micropores of diameters approximately 1.2 nm and less.
cln_elements.clean_text:
A luminescent triarylboron ligand functionalized with three carboxylic groups has been synthesized and fully characterized. Its use in boron-containing metal-organic frameworks (B-MOFs) has been demonstrated by the synthesis and isolation of a ZnIIB-MOF compound (B-MOF-1). The crystals of B-MOF-1 belong to the cubic space group F432 with 8-fold interpenetrated networks and ~21% void space. B-MOF-1 exhibits blue fluorescence and is capable of modest gas sorption of N2, argon, and CO2.

Ligand 1, a C 3-symmetric star-shaped molecule, was synthesized (Scheme ) by Suzuki coupling of tris(4-bromoduryl)borane (2) with excess boronic acid (3), yielding the triester (82% yield), followed by saponification with LiOH (89% yield). Free ligand 1 exhibits purple-blue fluorescence at 397 nm (λex = 330 nm, THF, 298 K, Φ = 0.03), which is comparable to the monotopic carboxylate ligand that we previously reported. Crystals of 1 obtained from a toluene and methanol solution belong to the monoclinic space group P21/c. In the crystal lattice, molecules of 1 form an extended, interweaved 2D hydrogen-bonded network via the three carboxylic groups, as shown in Figure . Toluene solvent molecules are found within and between the 2D networks of 1 (see the , SI).

Despite the high degree of interpenetration, the crystals of B-MOF-1 possess modest porosity as revealed by X-ray data (21% of void space; pore volume of 0.18 cm3 g-1 calculated from the crystal density 1.175 g cm-3 accounting for Zn1.5[L-1 -3](H2O)[(NH2Me2)NO3]. As shown in Figure , three different spherical void spaces of approximately 1.4, 0.7, and 0.2 nm in diameter are present in the crystal lattice. The porosity was further probed via gas physisorption analyses using both N2 and argon as the probe gases. The argon adsorption-desorption isotherms of B-MOF-1 are shown in Figure a as linear and semilogarithmic-scale plots. For comparison, the corresponding N2 adsorption data are presented in Figure S10 in the . In both cases, the isotherms are characteristic of a microporous material, with a type I isotherm, typical for most MOF materials. The physicochemical parameters derived from the inert gas adsorption analysis are compiled in Table S2 in the . The argon Brunauer-Emmett-Teller specific surface area and pore volume obtained for B-MOF-1 are 368 m2 g-1 and 0.19 cm3 g-1, respectively (ca. 406 m2 g-1 and 0.21 cm3 g-1 from the N2 sorption analysis), in good agreement with data from XRD analysis. Advanced pore-size analysis was performed by applying modern nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) method on the argon data assuming a cylindrical pore model for zeolitic/oxidic pores (see the ). The theoretical NLDFT isotherm fits the experimental data very well (see Figure S11 in the ). The data indicate that B-MOF-1 consists of mainly micropores of diameters approximately 1.2 nm and less.

metadata.title:
Luminescent Triarylboron-Functionalized
Zinc Carboxylate
Metal–Organic Framework
